MSE Symposium

'Perspectives' continue today
Dr. John Money, an authority
on sexual behavior, and Drs.
Phyllis and 'Eberhard
Kronhousen, outspoken
supporters of sexual freedom and
social reconstruction, will speak
this week in the MSE
Symposium.
Tuesday Drs. Kronhousen will
speak on "Group Sex and
Alternate Lifestyles." beginning
at 8 pm in Shriver Hall. Vocal
proponents of population
control, women's liberation,
ecology and the abolition of
sexual censorship, Drs.
Kronhousen are clinical
psychologists.
Pornography
They have edited and written
several hooks on pornography,
sexuality, and erotic art, in
addition to producing two
full-length documentaries. Drs.
Kronhausen recently opened the

International Museum of Erotic
Art ill San Francisco, based on
the famous International
Exhibitions of Erotic Art in
Sweden and Denmark in the late
60's.
The two doctors are pioneers
in the treatment of serious
emotional disturbances through
non-institutional psychotherapy
in which "the traditional couch
and office routine is replaced by
frank face-to-face encounter in a
casual social setting."
Money will deliver an
illustrated lecture Thursday on
"Exotic Sex and Imagery in
Sexual Hangups" at 4 pm in
Shriver Hall.
Director
A professor of medical
psychology, and associate
professor of pediatrics, Money is
the director of the
Psychohormonal Research Unit

at the Hopkins Medical School.
His areas of research include
medical psychology, behavioral
endocrinology, genetics, and
sexology. In addition to writing
"Sex errors of the Body" he was
co-editor of "Transexualism and
Sex Reassignment" and "Man
and Woman, Boy and Girl:
Differentiation and Dimorphism
of Gender Identity from
Conception to Maturity."
A member of the board of
directors of the Sex Information
and Education Council of the
United States (SIECUS), Money
is affiliated with the Erickson
Educational Foundation and the
Neighborhood Family Planning
Center. He has served as visiting
professor at the Children's
Hospital of Phildelphia, the
Albert Einstein College of
Medicine, and Harvard
University.

Montagu calls for understanding of roles
Dr. Ashley Montagu, social
biologist and anthropoligist,
called for a •"use of the different
sex roles as a function of
humanity not a mistaken
psychosis," as he addressed the
1974 MSE Symposium last
Friday on "Sex, Status, Gender,
and Society."
Montagu discussed sex from
biological and sociological
standpoints, contending that
though women are biologically
superior to men, they are
subordinated by society.
"Mistaking his prejudices for the
laws of nture constitutes one of
the oldest psychoses of man," he
noted, "and especially of man of
the masculine gender."
Utilizing anthropological and
medical evidence, Montagu
asserted that although men have
historically dominated societies
throughout the world, the
survival of the human species is
due largely to physical and
mental superiority of females.
The evidence seems to me
u nequivocably
to indicate that
by far the most
important role as
Provider was that of the female,
not alone for herself
and
Offspring but also for her

husband,"he explained.
He contended that the status
of females in modern society is
product of "socialization and
prenatal endocrine

He stated that "sex roles are
what we choose to make them"
even though "the discussion of

discussion of the role of the

game between Wilson-Wood and the DU

DU blatantly tackled Wilson-Wood

made by the official; the official
frequently made the line of scrimmage
favorable to DU; the official totally
ignored BIA regulations requiring him to
record all protests, at the time of the
protest.

starting off with other BIA business
before getting to the Wilson-Wood case. A
report was given dealing with other recent

part of the meeting was that the board
seemed to miss the major point of this
report, that praticipation amongst
dorminory teams was scarce. Then
Wilson-Wood was given the opportunity
to present its protest. The case as a whole

r

versus the official, and in fact, the BIA as
a whole, they set up a case in which

about DU, and its game tactics. Their case
was agianst the officiating, which should
have penalized those actions. The board
sat around the J and H rooms in Levering
Hall, sprawled over chairs, looking out
windows, talking with neighbors, laughing
and jeering as Wilson-Wood presented
itself in an admirable manner. If they
were not laughing, they were picking
their noses, which seems to be a favorite
pasttime of the BR board. Wilson-Wood
brought fifteen serious people to testify,
including an impartial _spectator from
outside the dorm. Unfortunately, they
were wasting their time. The facts of the
matter were that the official belongs to a
frat, and is a member of the GIA board,

tlhree- fourths of the BIA board is made
up of frat members. No vote was going to
go in favor of a dormitory; Wilson-Wood
their bid to replay the game under fairer
conditions. Wilson-Wood was wronged by
a group of unethical clowns, who don't
even have the common decency to
uphold their own rules. Wilson -Wood
was cheated out of a game they rightfully
won, and then cheated out of a fair
hearing by a biased boarded board of
nose-pickers.

students on this campus.

Protest: something must be done about the BIA
By WILLIAM FOSTER
Last week's semi-final flag football
game between Wilson-Wood and the DU
fraternity ended in great controversy. DU
was declared the winner by a margin of
6-0, but the game was heatedly protested
by, the Wilson-Wood team. I am sorry to
saythat I attended both the game, and the
protest hearing before the BIA board.
The facts protested by Wilson-Wood
were:only one official showed for the
game, while two officials are required by
BIA rules; three times Wilson-Wood
scored what seemed to everyone on the
sidelines as clearcut touchdowns, except
for the official, who nullified all three;
DU blatantly tackled Wilson-Wood
runners on several occasions, no call being
made by the official; the official
frequently made the line of scrimmage
favorable to DU; the official totally
ignored BIA regulations requiring him to
record all protests, at the time of the
protest.
Bored Board
The BIA board met last Friday,
starting off with other BIA business
before getting to the Wilson-Wood case. A
report was given dealing with other recent
BIA events. The interesting aspect of this
part of the meeting was that the board
seemed to miss the major point of this
report, that praticipation amongst
dorminory teams was scarce. Then
Wilson-Wood was given the opportunity
to present its protest. The case as a whole

r

was - handled from the wrong angle.
Instead of hearing a case of Wilson-Wood
versus the official, and in fact, the BIA as
a whole, they set up a case in which
Wilson -Wood was fighting DU.
Wilson-Wood, though, had no qualms
about DU, and its game tactics. Their case
was agianst the officiating, which should
have penalized those actions. The board
sat around the J and H rooms in Levering
Hall, sprawled over chairs, looking out
windows, talking with neighbors, laughing
and jeering as Wilson-Wood presented
itself in an admirable manner. If they
were not laughing, they were picking
their noses, which seems to be a favorite
pasttime of the BR board. Wilson-Wood
brought fifteen serious people to testify,
including an impartial _spectator from
outside the dorm. Unfortunately, they
were wasting their time. The facts of the
matter were that the official belongs to a
frat, and is a member of the GIA board,
Wilson-Wood was playing a frat, and
tlhree- fourths of the BIA board is made
up of frat members. No vote was going to
go in favor of a dormitory; Wilson-Wood
their bid to replay the game under fairer
conditions. Wilson-Wood was wronged by
a group of unethical clowns, who don't
even have the common decency to
uphold their own rules. Wilson -Wood
was cheated out of a game they rightfully
won, and then cheated out of a fair
hearing by a biased boarded board of
nose-pickers.

Something must be done about the
BIA. There is little structure in the
present set-up of BIA activities, and
consequently little participation. This is
especially evident in the dormitories,
They are not represented on the BIA
bpard. No _representation has led to no
participation. This is a competitive
school; why can't intramurals become a
part of that competition? The
dormitories must either be equally
represented on the BIA board, or they
should form their own intramural
competition, separate from the
fraternities. This could be accomplished
by the halving of funds now allocated to
the BIA by the Athletic Center. The best

alternative would be to restructure the
BIA, however. Colonel Serena, Bob Scott,
someone must help in this restructuring.
The honor code has undergone much
criticism lately in regard to academic
affairs. Here is another example of
dishonorable actions at Hopkins, the BIA
ruling in the Wilson- Wood case. The BIA
treats intramurals as a joke; they operate
in a half-assed way;in actuality the board
itself is a joke. Intramural activities, and
the direction and organization of them:
considerable work in these areas is
needed, if the BIA is to become a
reasonably fair and healthy competitive
organization for the benefit of all
students on this campus.
